--- title: "Effect Modification Analysis within the Propensity score Framework" author: "Mohammad Ehsanul Karim" format: html: toc: true number-sections: true editor: visual execute: cache: true --- ## Simulation First, we need to install the R package `simcausal`, which can be obtained from GitHub: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_4e6f515dd57a5656dc90caf5bab54e67'} ```{.r .cell-code} devtools::install_github('osofr/simcausal', build_vignettes = FALSE) ``` ::: We will use the following data-generation model: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_3ce556834b402725aeb1d9fdd5044354'} ```{.r .cell-code} require(simcausal) D <- DAG.empty() D <- D + node("age", distr = "rnorm", mean = 2, sd = 4) + node("gender", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(4)) + node("education", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(3 + 5* age)) + node("diet", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(1 -3 * education)) + node("income", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(2 - 5 * education - 4 * age)) + node("smoking", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(1 + 1.2 * gender + 2 * age)) + node("hypertension", distr = "rbern", prob = plogis(1 + log(3) * diet + log(1.3) * age + log(3.5) * smoking + log(0.5) * gender)) Dset <- set.DAG(D) plotDAG(Dset) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](chapter_07_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We can now generate an example dataset: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_60641942739348b2ae45589a9692371c'} ```{.r .cell-code} Obs.Data <- sim(DAG = Dset, n = 50000, rndseed = 123) Obs.Data$smoking <- as.character(Obs.Data$smoking) Obs.Data$income <- as.factor(Obs.Data$income) Obs.Data$income <- relevel(Obs.Data$income, ref = "1") ``` ::: Sample data from the hypothetical example of association between hypertension and smoking, where other variables such as income, age [centered], gender, education and diet also plays a role in the data generation process. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_de9a2919738abdf0f1b85faab7bc878c'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` age gender education diet income smoking hypertension 34901 12.288936 1 1 1 0 1 1 149 10.400436 1 1 0 0 1 1 10060 2.991820 1 1 0 0 1 0 22220 -4.311952 0 0 0 1 0 1 9979 -6.435549 0 0 0 1 0 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Effect measure assessment via adding interaction term Below, we estimate a logistic regression model to assess whether the effect of smoking (the exposure) on hypertension is modified by income. The covariates age and gender are confounders. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_26516b1d25716f598a1bd19979418142'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.w.em <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data) require(jtools) results.model <- summ(fit.w.em, model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, exp = TRUE) results.model ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
exp(Est.) 2.5% 97.5% z val. p
(Intercept) 5.46 4.37 6.82 14.97 0.00
smoking1 2.93 2.60 3.30 17.69 0.00
income0 0.48 0.41 0.57 -8.28 0.00
age 1.29 1.27 1.31 36.77 0.00
gender 0.54 0.43 0.67 -5.55 0.00
smoking1:income0 1.27 1.04 1.56 2.33 0.02
Standard errors: MLE
::: ::: The interaction term in `results.model` is statistically significant. ### Presentation of effect measures {.unnumbered} We can generate a summary report from aforementioned effect modification analysis. The table below depicts the adjusted odds ratios for income levels (`high = 0`, and `low = 1`) ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_453ab8129178300106059a46d4b1573d'} ```{.r .cell-code} require(interactionR) em.object <- interactionR(fit.w.em, exposure_names = c("income0", "smoking1"), ci.type = "mover", ci.level = 0.95, em = TRUE, recode = FALSE) em.object$dframe[,1:4] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Measures Estimates CI.ll CI.ul 1 OR00 1.0000000 NA NA 2 OR01 2.9301604 2.6010653 3.3008937 3 OR10 0.4832932 0.4068652 0.5740780 4 OR11 1.7997639 1.6334908 1.9829619 5 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==0] 2.9301604 2.6010653 3.3008937 6 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==1] 3.7239584 3.1434919 4.4116118 7 Multiplicative scale 1.2709060 1.0385052 1.5553143 8 RERI -0.6136898 -0.9754808 -0.2905171 ``` ::: ::: ## Effect measure assessment via stratified approach ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_0ee5f4e2e89d985b84204c47d01cd2e6'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.income1 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = subset(Obs.Data, income == 1)) fit.income0 <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking + age + gender, family=binomial(link = "logit"), data= subset(Obs.Data, income == 0)) ``` ::: The table below summarizes the adjusted odds ratios for smoking across the different income levels (`low = 1`, and `high = 0`) as obtained using the stratified approach. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_411e399494dcefe15ba2c36968659b4e'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Value of income exp(Est.) 2.5% 97.5% z val. p [1,] 1 3.066878 2.707961 3.473366 17.64728 1.067842e-69 [2,] 0 3.590260 3.023124 4.263792 14.57113 4.287200e-48 ``` ::: ::: We can investigate effect modification between income (the modifier) and all covariates as follows: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_ba1e194bbb466a52ef4cd8e550f2ee3e'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.all.int <- glm(hypertension ~ income * (smoking + age + gender), family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data) ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_25ac7983aae013a3504d7a39ce080e49'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Variable Units OddsRatio CI.95 p-value 1 income(1): smoking(1 vs 0) 3.07 [2.71;3.47] < 1e-04 2 income(0): smoking(1 vs 0) 3.59 [3.02;4.26] < 1e-04 ``` ::: ::: ## Interaction Assessment of interaction between smoking and income. We estimate a logistic regression model where - Outcome: `hypertension` - Exposure variables: `smoking` and `income` - Confounders: `age`, `gender`, and `education` An interaction term of smoking and income is added. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_98d575d510139bcc06f10cc438d842dc'} ```{.r .cell-code} fit.w.int <- glm(hypertension ~ smoking * income + age + gender + education, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = Obs.Data) results.int.model <- summ(fit.w.int, model.info = FALSE, model.fit = FALSE, exp = TRUE) results.int.model$coeftable ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` exp(Est.) 2.5% 97.5% z val. p (Intercept) 5.6937765 4.5570175 7.1141027 15.3077121 6.791105e-53 smoking1 3.3452459 2.9505339 3.7927612 18.8503257 2.920389e-79 income0 1.0908060 0.8506311 1.3987941 0.6849951 4.933470e-01 age 1.2981524 1.2804814 1.3160673 37.3150071 9.371499e-305 gender 0.5366777 0.4313229 0.6677666 -5.5815569 2.383750e-08 education 0.4233969 0.3502014 0.5118909 -8.8749618 6.995745e-19 smoking1:income0 1.1022535 0.8968615 1.3546825 0.9253438 3.547871e-01 ``` ::: ::: The interaction term between income and smoking is, however, not statistically significant. ### Presentation of effect measures {.unnumbered} ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_090ff8ad38389af3dd4d8337b51f714e'} ```{.r .cell-code} int.object = interactionR(fit.w.int, exposure_names = c("smoking1", "income0"), ci.type = "mover", ci.level = 0.95, em = FALSE, recode = FALSE) ``` ::: Summary report from an interaction analysis when investigating association between two exposure variables (smoking and income) and hypertension. Below, `CI.ll` and `CI.ul` depict the lower and upper limits of the 95 percent confidence intervals, `OR11` = $OR_{A = 1, M = 1}$ , `OR10` = $OR_{A = 1}$, `OR01` = $OR_{M = 1}$ and `OR00` captures the reference. ::: {.cell hash='chapter_07_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_4fac50fedab4bd15dfa5b4c9729f547b'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Measures Estimates CI.ll CI.ul 1 OR00 1.0000000 NA NA 2 OR01 1.0908060 0.850631061 1.3987941 3 OR10 3.3452459 2.950533888 3.7927612 4 OR11 4.0221386 3.287881778 4.9203713 5 OR(income0 on outcome [smoking1==0] 1.0908060 0.850631061 1.3987941 6 OR(income0 on outcome [smoking1==1] 1.2023447 0.997265811 1.4495962 7 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==0] 3.3452459 2.950533888 3.7927612 8 OR(smoking1 on outcome [income0==1] 3.6873089 3.112335708 4.3685026 9 Multiplicative scale 1.1022535 0.896861546 1.3546825 10 RERI 0.5860867 0.029944164 1.2657133 11 AP 0.1457152 -0.004274684 0.2598376 12 SI 1.2405887 1.008364517 1.5262937 ``` ::: :::
